docs.lead_paragraph: Since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is looking to cut more than $4 billion from the city's budget, now is perhaps not the most logical time for a city commissioner to be talking about expanding services. But that appears to be the central goal of Dr. Benjamin K. Chu, the city's new Health and Hospitals Corporation president. When Mr. Bloomberg chose Dr. Chu to take over the city's hospital system, he set up the first smooth transition in a decade for the corporation, where leaders had left under fire or in a fog of scandal, usually only to be replaced by other short-timers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The next time you feel like napping on the job, you might tell your boss about a German town named Vechta, southwest of Hamburg. For two years, civil servants there have been allowed 20 minutes after lunch to go home and take a nap, doze in their office chairs or otherwise relax. Vechta has found that the practice increases workers' efficiency. Frank Kaethler, a spokesman for the town, told Reuters that Vechta started the project because it had too much work for too few employees and no budget to hire new civil servants.

A loud snorer, he woke up frequently night after night gasping for breath. Heading off in the morning to his job running a mental health residence, he rarely felt refreshed. ''It's pretty bad,'' said Mr. Axinn, of South Setauket, having given up driving for fear of falling asleep at the wheel. ''I've been known to nod off in the middle of a meeting.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A 100-room hotel under construction in the historic port district here is one of several major projects under way around the city's working waterfront, even as debate goes on about how to balance preservation of marine industrial uses with the desire for more development. In addition to the $13 million Portland Harbor Hotel, scheduled to open in June, other development under way, recently completed or planned around this Casco Bay harbor includes two office buildings, two fish processing plants, another hotel, a marine research center and an aquarium, as well as expansion of the city's industrial, fishing and passenger terminal facilities. Together, it is hoped that these improvements will help keep one of the nation's oldest working ports vibrant.

docs.lead_paragraph: During a screening of the movie ''John Q.'' recently, I saw many in the audience spontaneously cheer for the working-class hero played by Denzel Washington. There were jeers, too, for the villains: the callous hospital administrator, the rich but indifferent cardiac surgeon and, of course, the sleazy H.M.O. The plot line is thin: John Q.'s little boy suddenly takes ill and needs a heart transplant, but John Q.'s H.M.O. won't cover the costs. His family earns too much to qualify for Medicaid or other assistance, and he has to shell out cash just to keep his son in the intensive-care unit. The hospital threatens to discharge the dying boy. A frustrated John Q. snaps and pulls a gun on the surgeon (to the loudest cheers in the audience) and takes over the E.R. In the end, John Q. prevails. The movie is laden with clichés and inaccuracies, and yes, it even romanticizes terrorism. But it was a box-office hit in its first week. Undoubtedly ''John Q.'' struck a chord: we are all angry (if only subconsciously) about the inequities in the system; we know health care needs reform; we are frustrated with Congress and the special-interest lobbies that keep it from happening. We, John Q. Public, personified by Denzel, are fighting back. The actor himself has said the movie made him more aware of the problem of the uninsured in America: ''I was amazed at how many people fall into that slot.'' He was referring to nearly 40 million Americans.

docs.lead_paragraph: The film ''A Beautiful Mind,'' about the Nobel Prize-winning mathematician John F. Nash Jr., portrays his recovery from schizophrenia as hard-won, awe-inspiring and unusual. What most Americans and even many psychiatrists do not realize is that many people with schizophrenia -- perhaps more than half -- do significantly improve or recover. That is, they can function socially, work, relate well to others and live in the larger community. Many can be symptom-free without medication. They improve without fanfare and frequently without much help from the mental health system. Many recover because of sheer persistence at fighting to get better, combined with family or community support. Though some shake off the illness in two to five years, others improve much more slowly. Yet people have recovered even after 30 or 40 years with schizophrenia. The question is, why haven't we set up systems of care that encourage many more people with schizophrenia to reclaim their lives?

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST month I called the Mount Kisco Medical Group to schedule my annual mammogram. The first available date for a routine screening was June 24. I called my mother to complain, but she could only commiserate. She had just scheduled hers at White Plains Hospital -- for mid-July. A huge amount of attention has been focused on mammograms recently. The breast cancer screening has been an annual routine for millions of American women, but a recent Danish report cited flaws from studies that doctors thought proved mammography saved lives. Advocates for mammography countered that it remains the best tool to lower breast cancer death rates.

docs.lead_paragraph: With low-priced competition looming for Claritin, the heavily advertised allergy drug, the Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it would offer a nonprescription version later this year. Analysts predicted a drugstore free-for-all that could drive down prices for consumers and severely erode Schering-Plough's profits in 2003. Claritin, which had sales of $2.7 billion last year, is expected to lose its main patent protection in December. It would then compete with copycat products promoted by marketing juggernauts like Johnson & Johnson and American Home Products, as well as store brands.
